source.query: bear hug carry step over muscles worked
source.raw_text:
The Bear-Hug Step-Over, a functional movement, primarily targets your core, glutes, and quads (legs) while improving posture, balance, and upper back mobility by mimicking carrying a heavy object (like with a sandbag or kettlebell) and stepping over an obstacle. It works the pectoralis major, anterior deltoids, and biceps for the "hug" and serratus anterior, rhomboids, and traps for shoulder blade control, enhancing overall full-body strength and coordination. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]  
Muscles Worked 

• Primary Movers (Legs & Core): 

    • Glutes & Quadriceps (Quads): Essential for lifting the leg over the obstacle and stabilizing the body. 
    • Core (Abs, Obliques, Lower Back): Maintains torso stability and prevents rounding during the carry and step. 

• Supporting & Stabilizing Muscles (Upper Body): 

    • Pectoralis Major & Anterior Deltoids (Chest & Front Shoulders): Engaged to maintain the "hug" position, squeezing the load. 
    • Serratus Anterior, Rhomboids, Trapezius (Upper Back): Work to control and protract the shoulder blades, crucial for wrapping them around the load. 
    • Biceps: Assist in flexing the elbows to hold the object close. 
    • Forearms/Grip: Key for holding the weight (sandbag, kettlebell). [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 7, 8, 9]  

Movement Patterns & Benefits 

• Loaded Carry Pattern: Simulates carrying heavy, awkward objects, building functional strength and improving grip and core endurance. 
• Dynamic Mobility: Improves thoracic (upper back) mobility and scapular (shoulder blade) protraction, helping with posture and breathing. 
• Full-Body Integration: Connects lower body power with upper body stability, training the body to move as one unit. 
• Balance & Coordination: The uneven load and stepping motion challenge balance and coordination, translating to real-life movements. [2, 3, 6, 8]  

How it Works (General Steps) 

1. Load: Secure a weight (sandbag, kettlebell) in a bear hug position (clutched to your chest). 
2. Carry/Walk: Walk with the weight held tight, focusing on bracing your core and squeezing the load. 
3. Step-Over: Step over an imaginary or physical obstacle, lifting your knees high and maintaining the hug. 
4. Repeat: Alternate sides for a continuous, full-body challenge. [3, 4, 5, 6, 10]
